Fig. 1 (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, (b) pore size curve, (c) XRD pattern of fresh catalyst and (d)XRD pattern of reduced catalyst. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM or HR-TEM images of support (a) SiO2, (b) MSS and fresh (c) Ni/SiO2, (d) Ni/MSS, (e) Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and (f) Ni/MSS@CeO2 and reduced (g) Ni/SiO2, (h) Ni/MSS, (I) Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and (j) Ni/MSS@CeO2; EDS mappings on the reduced (k) Ni/MSS, (L) Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and (m) Ni/MSS@CeO2 catalyst. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) Raman spectra of fresh catalyst and XPS spectra of Ce3d (b), O 1 s (c) and Ni 2p (d) of fresh catalyst. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS spectra of (a) Ce 3d, (b) O 1 s, (c) Ni 2p for reduced catalyst; (d) EPR spectra for reduced catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR (a), CO2-TPD (b), H2-TPD (c) and O2-TPD (d) profiles for various catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Catalytic activity and stability of different catalysts in DRM reaction. (a), (d) CH4 Moles conversions, (b),(e) CO2 moles conversions and (c), (f) H2/CO value. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TEM image (a) Ni/SiO2, (b) Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and (c) Ni/MSS@CeO2, XRD (d), TG (e), Raman (f) and O2-TPO (g) curves over catalyst after reaction. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Activation energy of different catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) CH4, (b) CO, (c) H2 and (d) CO2 signals detected during CH4-TPSR over reduced Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 catalysts. State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan Shanxi 030024 PR China The low-temperature carbon deposition resistance of Ni-based DRM catalysts supported on inert SiO2 can be improved by constructing oxygen vacancies. This work deeply explored the role of monodispersed mesoporous silica spheres (MSS) and non-porous SiO2 support layer structure on the structure and oxygen vacancies of sandwich Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 catalysts and their catalytic performance. The results show that Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 generated by high-temperature H2 reduction greatly increases the number of oxygen vacancies. In comparison to non-porous SiO2, the dual confinement effect of MSS's pore and CeO2 shell layer prevented Ni particles from sintering. The unique pore of MSS promotes the dispersion of Ni and CeO2, constructing more Ni-O-Ce active sites and enhancing the Ni-CeO2 interaction. It has low activation energy for decomposition of CH4 and CO2. In addition, the oxygen vacancies provided by the CeO2 shell notably inhibit carbon deposition and reduce the degree of graphitization. Ni/SiO2@CeO2 has more oxygen vacancies, but due to the high crystallinity, weak redox ability and strong thermal stability of Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2, the oxygen vacancies it produces cannot fully activate CH4 and CO2, and also cover some active sites of Ni. Ni/MSS@CeO2 resulted in minimal carbon deposits during a 30 h reaction under low-temperature and high space velocity. In situ DRIFT technology confirmed that Ni/MSS@CeO2 follows the HCOO* pathway. The oxygen species can react with the carbon species produced by CH4 decomposition. This work offers valuable insights for the design of efficient Ni-SiO2-CeO2 catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Oxygen vacancies DRM Carbon deposition Kinetic Mechanistic Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction As global efforts intensify to reach carbon neutrality, growing apprehensions about greenhouse gas emissions have heightened the need for sustainable energy alternatives. This urgency has driven significant research into advanced chemical technologies [1,2]. The dry reforming of methane (DRM) process has attracted significant attention in recent research. First, it effectively reduces atmospheric levels of two key greenhouse gases, lessening their climate impact [3,4]. Secondly, the resultant syngas serves as a valuable intermediary in the production of various fuels and chemicals. The capability to convert waste methane, such as that derived from landfills or biogas, into valuable products further underscores the economic and environmental benefits of DRM. Despite DRM's potential, its large-scale adoption is hindered by key challenges, including strong endothermicity and high operational temperatures, leading to substantial energy demands [5]. Meanwhile, sintering and carbon deposition may readily deactivate the catalyst under high temperature conditions [6]. Thus, there is an urgent industrial need to design efficient low-temperature DRM catalysts that mitigate carbon deposition and sintering. Precious metal catalysts, while exhibiting exceptional performance in terms of carbon tolerance and thermal stability, face significant deployment challenges due to their extravagant price point. Due to their cost-effectiveness and excellent catalytic performance, Ni-based catalysts have been widely employed [7]. Nevertheless, carbon accumulation and sintering often lead to catalyst deactivation [8]. Therefore, researchers have employed multiple strategies to improve the sintering resistance and carbon deposition tolerance of Ni-based DRM catalysts. In general, CeO2 is an important component in developing effective and stable DRM catalysts [9,10]. Adsorbed oxygen species at vacancy sites may effectively prevent carbon accumulation. The incorporation of low-valent cations (Sm3 +, Ni2+, Pr3+, Gd3+) or smaller high-valent ions (Si4+, Zr4+) into the CeO2 lattice induces structural defects or increase the number of Ce3+ can regulate catalyst's oxygen vacancies in the catalyst [7,11]. Wu et al. [12] demonstrated that incorporating smaller cations (Mg2+, Co2+, Zn2+) into the CeO2 lattice effectively modulated surface oxygen vacancy concentration. Their results revealed that the catalyst with the highest oxygen vacancy density exhibited optimal catalytic performance and stability. Zhou et al. [13] prepared a MOF-derived CeO2-loaded Ni DRM catalyst. Its Ni particles were more evenly dispersed and contained a higher oxygen vacancies proportion, which facilitated the CO2 breaking down into CO and reactive oxygen, thus showing better low-temperature catalytic performance. In addition, the embedding of metal cations into the ceria's fluorite structure will also change the physical and electronic structure of the oxide, thereby promotes the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) and enhancing its catalytic activity. Liu et al. [14] successfully synthesized a Ce1-xNixO2-y solid solution through isovalent substitution of Ni2+ ions into the ceria lattice. The strong Ni-Ce interaction significantly modified the electronic structure and chemical behavior of Ni species and promoted the cracking of CH4, showing excellent low-temperature DRM performance. Similarly, Strniša et al. [15] also discovered that the Ni-O-Ce solid solution was produced by incorporating Ni into the ceria lattice enhanced the SMSI effect and effectively facilitated the Ni particles distribution and enhanced the catalyst's stability. Furthermore, the researchers discovered that diminutive Ni nanoparticles exhibit remarkable resistance to carbon deposition compared to their larger counterparts; hence, regulating the size of Ni can improve the catalyst's resistance to carbon deposits [16,17]. At the same time, A well-designed porous support structure combined with optimized catalyst synthesis protocols can significantly improve the dispersion of active metal species, thereby notably reducing Ni nanoparticle size and enhancing catalytic performance [18]. Arjun et al. [19] found that compared with MCM-41 and nMPS (non-mesoporous silica), the appropriate organized pore of SBA-15 effectively suppressed the clumping of small Ni particles and decreased carbon deposits. Peng et al. [4] found that the unique three-dimensional dendritic structure successfully inhibited the agglomeration of Ni, yielding a particle size that consistently stayed under 5 nm. Moreover, the core-shell architecture has the capacity to inhibit the aggregation of nickel particles, and reducing carbon deposition [20,21]. Similarly, Han et al. [22] encapsulated Ni nanoparticles into S-1 zeolite. This special structure enabled the catalyst to exhibit excellent DRM stability under high space velocity. In contrast to core-shell designs, the sandwich structure allows the support and shell layers to function together in catalytic processes. Park et al. [23] examined the impact of different shell M (Al2O3, ZrO2, CeO2 and SiO2) on the DRM activity of NiMgAl@M. The study found that the Al2O3 layer can preserve minute Ni particles and maximize the most oxygen vacancies to the greatest extent. Das et al. [24] fabricated a CeO2-coated NiCo-MgAl catalyst derived from LDH, which served as both the support and active metal layer for dry reforming of methane. The study found that the unique layered structure of LDH enhances the formation of Ni-O-Ce active sites leads to superior catalytic activity. At the same time, the CeO2 shell layer dropped the deposition rate of carbon deposits dramatically at 600 ℃ reaction. Guo et al. [25]. coated CeO2 on Ni/SiO2 to prepare CeO2@Ni/SiO2 catalyst. The study found that the redox properties and strong surface alkalinity of CeO2 improved the catalyst's initial performance and operational stability. However, the solid sphere-based SiO2 support layer lacks a rich pore structure and has a relatively low relative area, resulting in a relatively oversized Ni particle size and poor dispersion of CeO2, so a significant accumulation of carbon deposits was observed at 700 °C. At the same time, our previous research discovered that the MSS support with invented cone pore can well disperse Ni nanoparticles, but its low-temperature carbon deposition resistance still needs to be improved. Furthermore, the researchers found that the SiO2 can modify the redox thermodynamics, facilitating CeO2 reduction under high-temperature conditions, generating cerium silicate with a large amount of Ce3+ present, thereby increasing its oxygen vacancies [26]. To date, no one has conducted in-depth research on increasing oxygen vacancies in Ni-CeO2-SiO2 reforming catalysts through high-temperature hydrogen reduction treatment. Therefore, we proposed the fabrication of a sandwich structure employing MSS with inverted conical pore as the support matrix and the enhancement of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst by high-temperature reduction to improve its resistance to carbon deposition. In this paper, two sandwich structure catalysts Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 were prepared with CeO2 as shell layer, non-porous SiO2 and inverted cone-shaped pore MSS as support layers, and increased the oxygen vacancy concentration by high-temperature H2 reduction. This study systematically investigated how the CeO2 shell coating and support layer architecture collectively influences the catalyst's anti-sintering properties and coking resistance. The results show that Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 generated by high-temperature H2 reduction can significantly increase the density of catalyst's oxygen vacancies. Simultaneously, the number of oxygen vacancies is related to the crystallinity of Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2. Although Ni/SiO2@CeO2 has more oxygen vacancies, but the formation of crystalline Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 demonstrates poor redox activity and strong thermal stability, leading to oxygen vacancies that are less effective in activating CO2 and CH4, and also cover some active sites of Ni. On the contrary, the unique pore of MSS enhances dispersion of both CeO2 and Ni, thereby constructing more Ni-O-Ce active sites and enhancing the Ni-CeO2 interaction. In addition, the oxygen vacancies provided by the low-crystallinity Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 significantly inhibit carbon deposition and reduce the degree of graphitization. In addition, the reaction mechanism was studied by kinetic experiments, surface chemical reactions of CH4 and CO2, and in situ infrared characterization. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The cyclohexane (C6H12), isopropyl alcohol ((CH3)2CHOH), ethanol (CH3CH2OH), ammonia solution (NH3·H2O), cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3.6H2O), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), hexamethylenetetramine ((CH2)6N4) and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) are obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesize SiO2 and MSS The fabrication technique for Mesoporous silica containing inverted cone pore (MSS) was outlined in prior work [27]. The specific synthesis process is presented in the supplemental material. Spherical SiO2 (Non-porous SiO2) particles were produced by a modified Stöber method [28]. First, 40 g of ethanol, 25 g deionized water, and 6.75 g of NH3·H2O were sequentially introduced into a beaker and agitated for 30 min. Following this, 14 g of TEOS was incrementally incorporated into the solution. Following a 6 h reaction, the resulting powder was obtained using centrifugation and washed. Following drying (60 °C), the powder was heat-treated at 550 °C for 3 h. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS 44 g of deionized water with 7.2 g of NH3·H2O (25 %) were added in a beaker. Subsequently, 3.78 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O was introduced to the mixture. Then, 2 g of MSS or SiO2 support were introduced and swirled for 4 h at 80 °C. After being filtered and washed, the material was dried (80 °C, 12 h) and finally heat-treated at 550 °C for 3 h. The theoretical Ni loading of the catalyst is 10 %, and the resulting catalysts were labeled Ni/MSS and Ni/SiO2, respectively. 2.2.3 Synthesize sandwich structure catalysts 3.0 mmol Ce(NH3)3·6 H2O and 1.0 g of Ni/MSS or Ni/SiO2 were added to 126 g of ethanol. Following 60 min of agitation, an aqueous solution containing 20 g of hexamethylenetetramine was introduced into the reaction mixture, which was subsequently heated to 70 °C and held at this temperature for 7 h. The product was collected by centrifugation, thoroughly washed, and dried at 80 °C overnight. Subsequent calcination at 600 °C for 3 h yielded the final catalysts, which were labeled as Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2. The preparation process of MSS@CeO2 is the same as that of Ni/MSS@CeO2, except that MSS is used instead of Ni/MSS. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The supplemental information provides detailed experimental procedures and comprehensive descriptions of the characterization instruments used in this study. 2.4 Catalyst performance The catalytic testing was performed in a quartz fixed-bed reactor, where 0.1 g of catalyst was homogeneously mixed with 0.6 g of quartz sand and packed between two quartz wool layers inside a quartz tube. A three-zone furnace maintained the catalyst bed within a uniform temperature region, with the reaction temperature monitored by a thermocouple positioned at the tube’s center and controlled via furnace settings. Prior to reaction, the catalyst was reduced in situ under pure H2 at 800 °C for 1 h. The system was then purged with N2 while cooling to 650 °C, at which point the DRM reaction was initiated by introducing a feed gas mixture of CO2 and CH4 (60 mL/min each; total GHSV = 72,000 mL·g−1·h−1). Catalytic performance was first evaluated through temperature-programmed testing (650–800 °C), followed by a stability assessment at 650 °C under isothermal conditions. After removal of condensed water, the gas effluent from the reactor was continuously monitored in real time using a GC-950 gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). CO, CO2, and CH4 were detected using hydrogen as the carrier gas, whereas argon was employed for the detection of H2. The following formula was used to compute the CH4 and CO2 molar conversion, as well as the H2/CO value of different catalysts [47]. (1) Specific A c tivity CH 4 ( Mols converted ) = CH 4 , in − CH 4 , out ( mols / min ) m Ni ( g ) (2) Specific Activity CO 2 ( Mols converted ) = CO 2 , in − CO 2 , out ( mols / min ) m Ni ( g ) (3) H 2 / CO = F H 2 , out F CO , out (4) Carbon balance % = F CH 4 , out + F CO 2 , out + F CO , out F CH 4 , in + F CO 2 , in × 100 % Where, CH4,in and CH4,out in formulas (1) and (2) stands for the CH4 molar flow rate of the inlet and outlet, respectively. CO2,in and CO2,out is the CO2 molar flow rate of the inlet and outlet. mNi is the true Ni content of the catalyst used in the evaluation process. Where Fout and Fin in formulas (3) and (4) stands for the volume flow rate of the outlet and inlet, respectively. It should be noted that the prepared sandwich structure catalyst and the uncoated CeO2 catalyst have different metal Ni contents. In order to more accurately compare the DRM performance of the catalysts, we calculated the CH4 and CO2 molar conversions of different catalysts using formulas (1) and (2) to compare the specific activities of different catalysts. Each data point used in testing was collected over three experiment repetitions. The analysis included computing standard deviations and assessing errors to handle data uncertainty. Results showing over 3 % error were deemed unreliable and removed. Full descriptions of the kinetic tests, in situ DRIFT conditions, and associated calculations can be found in the Supplementary Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical structure of catalyst The SiO2 spheres exhibit an H3-type hysteresis loop and a type II N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm (Fig. S1a), indicating that they have a wedge-shaped pore structure [29]. The mesoporous structure was confirmed by the observation of a type IV isotherm and H4 hysteresis loop in the MSS (Fig. S1a) [30,31]. The MSS is mainly composed of small pores of 3.5 nm caused by CTAB. There are pores of 4–13 nm formed by the adjacent silicon walls of silicon dioxide (Fig. S1b) [30]. The coexistence of small pores and mesopores makes MSS present a unique inverted cone pore structure. In contrast, SiO2 spheres have no pore distribution at 2–20 nm, indicating that there is almost no mesoporous pore structure on their surface, and only large pores of about 50 nm formed by sphere accumulation exist. Therefore, it can be seen from Table 1 that MSS has a higher pore volume (0.91 cm3/g) and specific surface area (570 m2/g), while SiO2 is only 0.16 cm3/g and 13 m2/g. The calcined Ni/SiO2 exhibits a Type IV adsorption isotherm, with an H4 hysteresis loop observed in the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.4–0.94 ( Fig. 1a). This indicates that the layered nickel silicate generated after loading Ni produces a mesoporous structure, with the pore size predominantly centered around 3.6 nm (Fig. 1b). Both pore volume and specific surface area showed enhancement, reaching 0.31 cm3/g and 136 m2/g, respectively (Table 1). Ni/MSS still has a an H4 hysteresis loop and a type IV adsorption isotherm, suggesting that MSS has good thermal stability, and that loading Ni and high-temperature calcination do not alter the support's structure. However, compared with the MSS, its pore volume and specific surface area are somewhat decreased. This phenomenon results from the generation of nickel phyllosilicate species, which consumes a certain amount of the MSS, and the reaction proceeds gradually from the outside to the inside [32]. No substantial differences were observed between the isotherm profiles and hysteresis loops of CeO2-coated catalysts and the original Ni/MSS and Ni/SiO2. This indicates the catalyst's fundamental structure was not altered by the CeO2 coating. Nevertheless, the catalysts exhibited marked declines in their specific surface areas and pore volumes. It demonstrates effective deposition of CeO2 inside the pores and on the Ni/MSS surface. This also indirectly indicates that the sandwich-like catalyst has been effectively constructed. Ni/MSS@CeO2 exhibited a more significant reduction, with its pore volume and specific surface area decreasing by approximately 44.3 % and 27.9 %. This is because some of the pores of nickel phyllosilicate in the Ni/SiO2 are blocked by CeO2, which is distributed throughout its porous branches [33]. On the contrary, the MSS itself has a unique inverted cone pore structure, and its CeO2 can also be deposited in the inverted cone pore structure. This also helps to form more Ni-O-Ce sites. As shown in Fig. S2, the reduced catalyst exhibited nearly identical N2 physisorption behavior and pore size distribution characteristics to the calcined catalyst, indicating that the catalyst's overall structure remained intact after H₂ reduction. A significant reduction in the pore volume and specific surface area of the decreased catalyst was observed (Table 1). In particular, the reduced Ni/SiO2@CeO2 catalyst's pore volume and specific surface area are only 0.12 cm3/g and 27 m2/g. It is because the reduction reaction causes the decomposition of nickel layered silicate and destroys its layered structure [33]. However, the Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 catalyst's pore sizes are still maintained around 3.5 nm. This will allow CH4 and CO2 to diffuse to the active sites Ni for reaction during the DRM process. In addition, high temperature H2 reduction in CeO2 and SiO2 systems will lead to changes in the catalyst phase composition, which in turn affects its pore volume and specific surface area [34]. ICP testing was performed on the catalysts to ascertain the accurate loading of metals and CeO2. The Ni/MSS, Ni/SiO2, Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 have respective Ni loadings of 8.9 %, 10.5 %, 5.3 %, and 6.7 %. The CeO2 loadings on Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 are 29.7 % and 32.8 % (Table1). The fresh catalysts Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS have obvious amorphous SiO2 characteristic diffraction peaks at 22.0°, and characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni3Si2O5(OH)4 at 60.5°, 36.7° and 34.1° (Fig. 1c), which correspond to the 60, 202 and 200 crystal planes [32]. However, not all characteristic peaks of nickel phyllosilicate are present, because the crystallinity of layered nickel phyllosilicate prepared by ammonia evaporation is not high [32]. After CeO2 coating, Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 only showed characteristic diffraction peaks of CeO2 [11,12]. This indicates CeO2 was effectively covered on the Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS surfaces, and other substances such as Ni were distributed uniformly throughout the support surface. The Scherrer-derived CeO2 crystal sizes measured 3.8 nm (Ni/SiO2@CeO2) and 2.9 nm (Ni/MSS@CeO2). This is because CeO2 can only be coated on the outer surface of SiO2. On the contrary, it can be dispersed in the pore structure of MSS, making it present a good dispersion. In addition, the XRD curves for MSS@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 were almost overlapped (Fig. S3a). And, the diffraction peak position of the 111 crystal plane of CeO2 for MSS@CeO2 was 28.55°. While the Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 shows shifts to 28.64° and 28.69° (Fig. S3b). The CeO2 lattice parameter for MSS@CeO2 remains unchanged (5.4157 Å), identical to pure CeO2. However, upon Ni loading, the fresh Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 catalysts display lattice contractions, with values of 5.3860 Å and 5.3949 Å, respectively. This signifies that a portion of Ni2+ is integrated into the CeO2 lattice, leading to the generation for the Ni-Ce solid solution [15]. The reduced catalysts Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS display the distinctive diffraction peaks of Ni at varying intensities at angles of 2θ = 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° (Fig. 1d) [31,35]. This indicates that after high-temperature reduction, Ni3Si2O5(OH)4 decomposes into SiO2 and Ni with different particle sizes [36]. Further calculations indicate that the Ni crystal sizes in Ni/MSS and Ni/SiO2 are 5.7 and 7.7 nm, respectively. This demonstrates that the distinctive inverted pores successfully restrict the clustering of Ni particles, enhancing Ni distribution. Interestingly, the CeO2 diffraction peaks in the reduced sandwich structure catalysts became indistinct, and new characteristic reflections corresponding to cerium silicate (Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2) emerging. This phenomenon results of the slow reduction of Ce4+ ions in CeO2 to Ce3+ ions during the high-temperature H2 reduction process, and further combines with SiO2 to form cerium silicate [34]. Simultaneously, the disparity in diffraction peak intensities between the two catalysts may be ascribed to differences in the pore size and specific surface area of the MSS and SiO2. Rocchini et al. [26] found that the formation of cerium silicate was significantly correlated with the CeO2 content. The Ni/SiO2@CeO2 exhibits a small specific surface area and a poorly pore structure, and CeO2 can only be loaded on the outer surface of SiO2 and its particle size is large. This also increases the local CeO2 content, allowing for a deeply reaction with SiO2 to produce highly crystalline Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2. In contrast, the unique inverted cone-shaped pores of MSS allow part of CeO2 to be distributed in its pores. The SiO2 on the same contact surface results in a relatively small amount of surface CeO2, resulting in a smaller crystallinity of Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 [34]. In comparison to the uncoated CeO2 catalyst, the diffraction peak strength of the Ni decreased for sandwich structure catalyst following the reduction, signifying that the CeO2 facilitated the Ni particles distribution in an efficient manner. The SiO2 is a solid sphere with no pores inside ( Fig. 2a-1), while MSS has inverted cone-shaped pores that are small inside and large outside (Fig. 2b-1). On the fresh Ni/SiO2 catalyst's spherical outer surface, a coating of fibrous Ni3Si2O5(OH)4 is present (Fig. 2c-1). However, the Ni3Si2O5(OH)4 distribution of Ni/MSS is more uniform due to its inverted cone pore structure (Fig. 2d-1). This is because NH3·H2O can also infiltrate the pores of MSS during the preparation procedure, promoting the distribution of Ni3Si2O5(OH)4. The fibrous Ni3Si2O5(OH)4 of Ni/SiO2@CeO2 becomes fuzzy (Fig. 2e-1) and the HR-TEM image of Ni/SiO2@CeO2 observed the 200 and 111 crystal planes of CeO2 (Fig. 2e-2), This implies that CeO2 was effectively deposited on the external surface of Ni/SiO2. Similarly, the fibrous Ni3Si2O5(OH)4 of Ni/MSS@CeO2 disappears, and no obvious pore structure is observed in the catalyst (Fig. 2f-1), which shows that CeO2 successfully covers the pores and outer surface of MSS. Additionally, the (200) and (111) lattice planes of CeO2 can be clearly observed on the outer surface of Ni/MSS@CeO2 in Fig. 2f-2. Regarding the reduced Ni/SiO2, the Ni nanoparticles formed during Ni3Si2O5(OH)4 decomposition are mostly located on its outer surface, while are distributed not only on the outer surface but also in the inverted cone pores for Ni/MSS (Fig. 2g-1 and h-1). Meanwhile, it is observed that the inverted cone-shaped pore of the reduced Ni/MSS still exists. Furthermore, statistics show that the Ni particle diameters in Ni/MSS and Ni/SiO2 are 6.6 nm and 7.6 nm (Fig. S4). These results demonstrate that MSS's distinctive porosity enhances Ni particle distribution and prevent their clumping together. The Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 remain spherical after reduction (Fig. 2i-1 and j-1), which shows that the coat of CeO2 and the process of high-temperature reduction did not alter the catalyst's morphology. However, a dense layer appeared on the sphere surface, which was ascribed to the shell layer of CeO2 species. Furthermore, the pores of Ni/MSS@CeO2 become blurred, indicating that CeO2 successfully covers the pores and outer surface of MSS. As shown in HR-TEM images 2i-2 and 2j-2, the (111) crystal plane of Ni is represented by a lattice spacing of 0.205 nm. The lattice spacings of 0.214 nm and 0.225 nm near the Ni particles are the 113 and 221 crystal planes of Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 [33,37]. Interestingly, no crystal planes corresponding to CeO2 were found. This phenomenon occurs because during reduction, Ce4+ were transformed into Ce3+ and subsequently interacting with Si4+ ions incorporated in the CeO2 lattice, forming Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 [34]. Furthermore, the dispersion of Ce and Ni catalysts is investigated by EDS mappings. The Ni particles is highly dispersed in the pores and outer surface of MSS (Fig. 2k-1). Its Ni distribution range of Ni/MSS@CeO2 is wider and the accumulation area is less, which suggests that a CeO2 layer's presence enhances the dispersal of Ni particles (Fig. 2m-1). After coating with CeO2, Ce species are distributed on the SiO2 and MSS surfaces and highly combined with Ni species. This shows that the effective fabrication of a sandwich-type catalyst architecture, where either SiO2 or MSS serves as the support matrix, CeO2 forms the outer shell, and Ni nanoparticles are precisely incorporated as the interlayer. The difference is that the Ni and Ce species in Ni/SiO2@CeO2 are concentrate on periphery the external sphere surface (Fig. 2L-1). The Ni/MSS@CeO2 catalyst demonstrates superior dispersion characteristics for both Ni and Ce species, which can be distributed around the external surface of MSS or dispersed in the inverted cone pores, thus constructing more Ni-O-Ce interfaces. This will enhance the DRM performance. The Ce and Ni distribution areas are basically consistent in the sandwich catalyst's EDS-mapping diagram, which indicates that Ni and Ce have a strong interaction. 3.2 Oxygen vacancies Fig. 3a displays the fresh sandwich structure catalyst's Raman spectra. The Ni/MSS@CeO2, Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and MSS@CeO2 exhibit characteristic Raman active F2 g bands at 461.6.7, 464.4 and 465.7 cm−1. These bands represent the oxygen atoms' symmetrical stretching around the Ce-O8 unit cation [11]. For pure CeO2, the F2 g band position is 465.8 cm−1. The F2 g bond position of MSS@CeO2 is the same as that of pure CeO2. However, the redshift of F2 g vibration modes in both Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 confirms lattice incorporation of Ni2+ ions into the CeO2 fluorite structure to generate a solid solution of Ni-Ce, causing structural distortion and generating topological defects [12,38]. Meanwhile, Ni/MSS@CeO2 has the large st shift, which is corresponds to the lower particle size of CeO2. The 2TA bands corresponding to Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 at 220 cm−1 further demonstrate that the CeO2 lattice has structural defects [11]. A broad defect-induced band (D) regarding the building of oxygen vacancies (VO) appears at 500–700 cm−1. [11] Further, it is divided into extrinsic defects (De) and intrinsic defects (Di). Generally, the catalyst's VO can be quantified by the D/F2 g area ratio [11,39]. The higher AD/AF2g ratio of Ni/MSS@CeO2 (0.50) compared to Ni/SiO2@CeO2 (0.38) demonstrates that a greater oxygen vacancy concentration for Ni/MSS@CeO2 (Table S1). Fig. 3b displays the Ce 3d spectra of the fresh catalysts MSS@CeO2 Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2. The identification on Ce3+ and Ce4+ ions may be achieved by analyzing the spin-orbit splitting of 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 orbitals [11]. The spectrum can deconvolves into ten characteristic peaks, where the peaks v0 (880.6 eV), v′ (885.6 eV), u0 (899.1 eV) and u′ (903.7 eV) components confirm the presences of Ce3+ ions [40,41]. The other peaks (u′′′, u′′, u, v′′′, v′′ and v) correspond to Ce4+ ions, exhibiting binding energies at approximately 916.6 eV, 906.2 eV, 901.1 eV, 898.1 eV, 887.7 eV and 882.7 eV. In addition, the concentration of Ce3+ species directly connected with the density of oxygen vacancies (OV) on the CeO2 surface. The quantity of oxygen vacancies rises in tandem with the Ce3+ concentration [42]. Therefore, the Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) value may be used to measure the oxygen vacancy concentration. The peak area sizes of Ce3+ and Ce4+ after fitting of different catalysts are shown in Table S2. Obviously, the Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratios for MSS@CeO2, Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 are 0.07, 0.11 and 0.14, indicating that Ni/MSS@CeO2 contains a higher density of oxygen vacancies. This indicates that in the fresh sandwich structure catalyst, it forms a part of Ni-CeO2 solid solution, resulting in CeO2 lattice defects, which essentially raises the oxygen vacancy density of the catalyst. Meanwhile, the lattice defect degree of CeO2 in Ni/MSS@CeO2 is greater. The sandwich structure catalyst's O 1S curves can be deconvoluted into three peaks (Fig. 3c). The spectral features at 530.6 eV (denoted as Oα) correspond to lattice oxygen [43]. The peaks (Oβ) at 532.3 eV are attributed to chemically adsorbed oxygen or surface OH groups [41,44]. Usually, the chemically adsorbed oxygen in XPS comes from the carbonate formation at oxygen vacancy sites [21]. Thus, the relative percentage of Oβ can serve as a quantitative indicator for determining oxygen vacancy concentrations in the catalyst. The single peak (Oγ) centered at 533.1 eV is the oxygen bond in SiO2 or nickel layered silicate [45,46]. Obviously, the Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) ratios for Ni/MSS@CeO2, MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 are 0.21, 0.12 and 0.16 (Table S3). Ni/MSS@CeO2 shows significantly greater oxygen vacancy concentration than other catalysts, which aligns with the analysis of Ce spectra. The Ni 2p spectra of fresh catalyst (Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2) were similar (Fig. 3d). At about 856.7 eV and 874.5 eV are Ni2+ ions of nickel phyllosilicate [47]. At the same time, there are satellite peaks of Ni at about 865 eV and 887 eV. However, there are no characteristic peaks corresponding to Ni0 particles, which indicates that Ni is present in the fresh catalyst as Ni2+. Fig. 4a displays that the Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratios for reduced Ni/MSS@CeO2, Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and MSS@CeO2 are 0.38, 0.47 and 0.35 (Table S4). The reduced catalyst's oxygen vacancy concentration rose significantly in comparison to the fresh catalyst. Interestingly, the reduced catalyst's oxygen vacancy concentration is in the range of MSS@CeO2<Ni/MSS@CeO2<Ni/SiO2@CeO2, contrasting sharply with the fresh catalyst series where Ni/MSS@CeO2 showed maximal vacancy concentration. At high temperatures (>500 °C) or in a reducing atmosphere (H2 or CO), oxygen atoms in the CeO2 lattice detach, forming oxygen vacancies and releasing O2 while Ce4+ is reduced to Ce3+ to maintain charge balance. Therefore, the more Ce3+ ions there are, the higher the oxygen vacancy concentration of the catalyst. The researchers found that the presence of SiO2 promotes the reduction of CeO2. Under high-temperature H2 conditions, Ce4+ undergoes reduction to Ce3+, subsequently reacting with SiO2 to form Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2. Most of the Ce ions in Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 exist in the form of + 3 valence, so additional oxygen vacancies are needed to compensate for the charge [26,34]. At the same time, the higher the crystallinity, the more Ce3+ there is. Therefore, the high crystallinity of Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 in Ni/SiO2@CeO2 leads to a higher oxygen vacancy density. The elevated oxygen vacancy concentration in reduced Ni/MSS@CeO2 compared to MSS@CeO2 suggests partial Ni-Ce solid solution phases preservation despite reduction treatment. Fig. 4b shows the reduced catalysts' O 1 s spectra. Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS only have a single peak (Oγ) centered at 533.2 eV, corresponding to the oxygen bonds in SiO2 [45]. The peaks corresponding to lattice oxygen (Oα) and chemically adsorbed oxygen or surface OH groups (Oβ) are missing, indicating that the CeO2 interlayer makes a lot of oxygen vacancies available. The Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) values with two reduced catalysts Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 are 0.35 and 0.40 (Table S5), respectively, and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 contains more oxygen vacancies. The existence of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface was indicated by the sandwich structure catalysts' clear peaks at g = 2.002, which were revealed by further EPR characterization investigation of the reduced catalysts (Fig. 4d). The peak intensity follow the order: MSS@CeO2＜Ni/MSS@CeO2＜Ni/SiO2@CeO2. This once again proves that the high crystallinity Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 produces more oxygen vacancies, and the addition of some Ni particles causes CeO2 lattice defects to produce a small amount of oxygen vacancies. Both reduced Ni/MSS and Ni/SiO2 catalyst's Ni 2p spectra were similar (Fig. 4c). The peaks seen at 852.8 eV and 869.8 eV align with Ni0 particles formed during the reduction of nickel phyllosilicate. These particles are related with the Ni 2 P3/2 and Ni 2 P1/2 orbitals [33]. At about 856.7 eV and 874.5 eV are Ni2+ ions of unreduced nickel phyllosilicate or Ni0 species that are oxidized after reduction. At the same time, there are satellite peaks of Ni at about 865 eV and 887 eV. However, the catalyst's Ni 2p spectrum is drastically different after coating with CeO2. The Ni 2p XPS spectra of both Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 become particularly weak, which suggests that the Ni particles in the sandwich structure have changed significantly. Its low surface concentration cannot be successfully detected by X-rays. This also indirectly indicates that CeO2 was uniformly coated on the Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS surfaces to form a sandwich structure. And, in contrast to Ni/SiO2@CeO2, the binding energy of Ni0 peak in Ni/MSS@CeO2 moves toward the high energy direction, indicating that it has a strong Ni-CeO2 interaction [39]. The Ni0/Ni2+ values of Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS are 0.41 and 0.55 (Table S6). The enhanced Ni dispersion in the Ni/MSS catalyst results in a higher abundance of Ni0 species, which is primarily attributed to the distinctive pore structure. Furthermore, the inverted pores contain a restricted number of Ni particles, leading to a decrease in the level of oxidation [19]. Generally, high Ni0 particles make CH4 cracking easier, resulting in a high conversion [48]. 3.3 Chemical adsorption analysis Fig. S5 illustrates the H2-TPR profile of CeO2. Obviously, at 370 °C, 500 °C, and 770 °C, the H2 consumption peak shows three separate peaks that correspond to the reduction of surface oxygen, surface lattice oxygen species and interior lattice oxygen [49,50]. As shown in Fig. 5a, the reduction peak of MSS@CeO2 shifts toward the low temperature than that of CeO2, suggesting that the addition of SiO2 encourages the CeO2 reduction. Rocchini. et al. [51] et al. observed that adding SiO2 to CeO2 can overcome the thermodynamics of CeO2 reduction process through high-temperature reduction, and the proportion of Ce3+ in the generated cerium silicate can reach 80 %. This also helps to increase the catalyst's oxygen vacancies. All catalysts have three different H2 reduction peaks, and the peaks centers of the Ni/SiO2 are concentrated at 423 °C, 576 °C and 698 °C. Ni/MSS is at 387 °C, 533 °C and 677 °C. Generally, reduction peak (< 450 °C) was the reduction of NiO, which has a weak metal support interaction [19,52]. The peak (450–600 ℃) was the reduction of the generated 1:1 nickel silicate, which has a strong metal support interaction. The reduction peak centered at about 700 °C corresponds to the 2:1 nickel silicate reduction, which is relatively more difficult to reduce [33,36]. Therefore, in order to completely reduce nickel phyllosilicate to active Ni0 particles, the reduction temperature of the catalyst was set to 800 °C. Researchers have shown that phyllosilicate nickel with strong interaction may successfully prevent Ni particles from clumping together, enhancing the catalyst's anti-sintering properties [32]. In addition, the Ni particles formed by the reduction of nickel silicate have a smaller particle size, and the small-sized Ni particles exhibit suppressed carbon formation, thereby enhancing both catalytic activity and long-term stability through improved anti-coking properties. The Ni/MSS showed a forward-shifted reduction peak in contrast to Ni/SiO2. Moreover, Ni/MSS demonstrated higher H2 consumption (440.5 μmol/g) compared to Ni/SiO2 (369.3 μmol/g) (Table S7). This suggests that the distinctive pore of MSS promotes the Ni2+ ions reduction. The initial reduction peak (< 350 °C) seen in Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 correspond to the reduction of readily reducible oxygen species associated with CeO2 surface vacancies, along with weakly bound NiO species. Typically, when incorporation of Si4+ or Ni2+ ions into the CeO2 lattice typically induces structural distortion and charge imbalance, consequently generating oxygen vacancies [12,42]. And the species adsorbed in this oxygen vacancy can be readily reduced at low temperatures [33]. The second peak refers to the process of converting Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the CeO2 surface and 1:1 nickel silicate [45]. The high-temperature reduction peak corresponded to the reduction of 2:2 nickel silicate and lattice oxygen in CeO2. After coating with CeO2, the peak's center temperature during reduction shifted toward low temperature and its H2 consumption increased, which indicated that the coating of CeO2 facilitated the Ni2+ reduction and yielded a significant quantity of oxygen vacancies. Simultaneously, Following CeO2 coating, Ni/MSS@CeO2 exhibits a higher reduction temperature than Ni/SiO2@CeO2, suggesting stronger Ce-Ni interactions in the MSS-based system. The CO2 desorption profiles for all catalyst systems exhibited three well-resolved peaks (Fig. 5b), indicating multiple types of adsorption sites. Desorption in the 100–250 °C range is characteristic of weakly basic sites, where CO2 is primarily adsorbed as bicarbonate species [32]. Desorption occurring between 250 and 500 °C was attributed to medium-alkaline sites, which are related to bidentate carbonate formations [53]. The peaks over 500 °C represent strong alkaline sites [54]. Clearly, all five catalysts possess a considerable number of weak and medium-strength basic sites, but no strong basic sites are present. Numerous studies indicate that weakly to moderately alkaline sites exhibit higher efficiency in CO2 adsorption and catalytic reactivity [54]. Furthermore, during the dry reforming of methane, CH4 tends to react more readily with carbonates formed by CO2 adsorption on weakly basic sites [46,55]. A greater CO2 desorption peak area was observed for Ni/MSS when compared to Ni/SiO2 (Fig. 5b) due to the distinctive pore structure of MSS, which improvement in Ni dispersion consequently leads to enhanced CO2 adsorption capacity. The peak areas of sandwich structure catalysts are substantially bigger than without CeO2 coating catalyst. This indicates that the CeO2 coating significantly improves the basicity due to the existence of many oxygen vacancies. Simultaneously, the center position of the CO2 desorption peak moves toward the low temperature direction. This suggests that the percentage of weak and medium alkaline sites is increased by the CeO2 coating, which can boost the CO2 activation [46]. The basicity order was Ni/SiO2＜Ni/SiO2@CeO2＜MSS@CeO2＜Ni/MSS@CeO2 (Table S8). The catalyst Ni/MSS@CeO2 exhibits higher CO2 adsorption performance compared to MSS@CeO2, indicating that the Ni-O-Ce interface created post-Ni loading increases the catalyst's CO2 adsorption. This further confirms that CO2 is primarily adsorbed at the Ni-CeO2 interface. Additionally, Ni/MSS@CeO2 possess a higher density of Ni-O-Ce active sites and exhibits stronger basicity compared to Ni/SiO2@CeO2. Fig. 5c displays the catalysts' H2-TPD pattern. Except for MSS@CeO2, other catalysts have a wide hydrogen desorption peak extending from 40 to 350 °C, which refers to the chemically adsorbed hydrogen that is attached to the surface of highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles [48,56]. Unlike the uncoated CeO2 catalyst, the peak area of H2 desorption in sandwich structure catalysts is greatly diminished, and the center position of the peak moves toward the high temperature direction. This means that the sandwich structure of CeO2 obstructs the adsorption of H2 at the active sites. In addition, MSS@CeO2 also shows a weak H2 desorption peak at 150 ℃ to 300 ℃, which indicates that the oxygen vacancies generated by CeO2 can also adsorb a small amount of H2. Furthermore, we calculated the ranking of the metal dispersion for the catalysts as follows: Ni/SiO2@CeO2＜Ni/SiO2＜Ni/MSS@CeO2＜Ni/MSS ( Table 2). First, the clustering of Ni particles is effectively suppressed by the pores of MSS, leading to promote dispersion. However, the Ni particles derived from phyllosilicate thermal degradation can only be dispersed throughout the external surface of SiO2, and the Ni particle size is larger. Secondly, high-temperature reduction can lead to Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 formation, which may block Ni surfaces, resulting in a reduction in exposed active sites and preventing it from adsorbing H2. Previous studies [57] demonstrated that reduction at elevated temperature (≥873 K) causes Ni nanoparticles to be covered with a thin layer of ceria, resulting in a reduction in active sites, which was not favorable for CH4 and CO2 conversion. The oxygen adsorption characteristics of the catalyst were investigated by O2-TPD characterization. The profile exhibited three well-defined peaks (α, β, γ) corresponding to temperature ranges of 45–300 °C, 300–600 °C and 600–700°C, respectively (Fig. 5d). The α peak is related to weakly bound or surface oxygen species on the catalyst surface, the β peak comes from active oxygen species (O2 -, O2 2-) bound to oxygen vacancies, and the γ peak is related to lattice oxygen species (O2-) [12,45]. Generally, active oxygen species (O2 -, O2 2-) can act as active sites to promote the activation of CO2 and CH4, thereby inhibiting the formation of carbon deposits during the reaction. As shown in Table S9, the O2 desorption peak area of the sandwich structure catalyst is significantly higher than that of the catalyst without CeO2 coating, indicating that the coating of CeO2 improves the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for oxygen species. Furthermore, the Ni/MSS@CeO2 catalyst exhibits the largest β peak area, suggesting the highest concentration of active oxygen species, with the following trend: Ni/SiO2＜Ni/MSS＜Ni/SiO2@CeO2＜MSS@CeO2＜Ni/MSS@CeO2. Although Ni/SiO2@CeO2 contains more oxygen vacancies, its active oxygen species (β peak) are less than Ni/MSS@CeO2. This is because the weak redox ability and high thermal stability of Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 result in oxygen vacancies being restricted by the rigid skeleton of SiO4 and it is difficult to generate active oxygen species [51]. This was further confirmed by subsequent CH4/CO2-TPSR characterization. In addition, Ni/MSS@CeO2 exhibits a higher concentration of active oxygen species compared to MSS@CeO2, demonstrating that defect sites generated by Ni2+ incorporation into the CeO2 lattice are beneficial to the generation of active oxygen species. 3.4 Catalytic DRM performance Figs. 6a–c illustrates the DRM catalyst activity at various reaction temperatures. Elevating the reaction temperature from 650 to 800 °C resulted in greater CO2 and CH4 molar conversion by the catalyst, as well as higher H2/CO values. For example, the CH4 and CO2 molar conversion for Ni/MSS@CeO2 at 650° C are 0.211 and 0.267 mol·min−1·gNi −1. They are 0.429 and 0.449 mol·min−1·gNi −1 at 800 ℃. This occurs since the dry reforming of methane (DRM) is an endothermic process thermodynamically, and higher temperatures drive the reaction forward [58]. Due to the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction, all catalysts exhibit lower CH4 molar conversion compared to CO2 molar conversion. This effect also leads to H2/CO ratios deviating from unity [8,47]. Ni/MSS shows better DRM performance than Ni/SiO2 at the same temperature due to its unique pore structure enhancing metal dispersion. Meanwhile, its high metal reduction degree gives it more active sites. It should be highlighted that MSS@CeO2 demonstrated no catalytic activity owing to the absence of active Ni particles. The CeO2-coated catalysts (Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2) exhibit significantly improved CH4 and CO2 molar conversion efficiencies relative to their uncoated counterparts. This is because CeO2 enhances the Ni species reduction and creates a substantial quantity of oxygen vacancies, which enhances CO2 and CH4 activation. Meanwhile, Ni/MSS@CeO2 exhibited the best catalytic activity because of more Ni-O-Ce active sites and strong Ni-CeO2 interactions. Nevertheless, the H2/CO ratios of sandwich structure catalysts are inferior than those of Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS. This is because the large amount of oxygen vacancies offered by CeO2 encourages CO2 adsorption and activation, increases CO2 conversion and intensifies the reverse water gas reaction [33]. It is worth noting that, as shown in Fig. S7a, the CH4 and CO2 molar conversions of the prepared Ni/CeO2 catalyst are the lowest, even lower than those of Ni/SiO2. When the reaction temperature is 650 °C, the CH4 and CO2 molar conversions are 0.055 and 0.074 mol·min−1·gNi −1. This may be because during the reduction process at 800 °C, the CeO2 grains grow and wrap around the Ni active particles, resulting in a reduction in metal active sites. This also highlights the importance of the sandwich structure we constructed. The catalyst's carbon balance at various reaction temperatures ranged from 97 % to 102 %. (Fig. S6a), indicating that no carbon deposits were produced. Ni/MSS@CeO2 demonstrated superior CH4 reaction rates when benchmarked against previously reported catalyst systems (Fig. S8). The representative catalysts are shown in detail in the supporting information (Table S10). The anti-sintering properties and carbon deposition resistance of the CeO2-modified catalyst were assessed through stability testing at 650 °C, with results presented in Fig. 6d-f. For Ni/SiO2, the CO2 and CH4 molar conversion decreased rapidly within 2 h and then slowly decreased within the next 6 h. Following 8 h of reaction, the catalyst bed became obstructed and the pressure at the intake of the reactor exceeded the desired level, forcing the reaction to terminate. The Ni/SiO2 exhibited lower CO2 and CH4 molar conversion than Ni/MSS. This was explained by the fact that MSS encouraged active metals to disperse and that its tiny Ni particle size successfully prevented carbon deposits from forming [59]. In addition, its unique inverted cone pore structure and strong basicity promoted the contact rate between CO2 and C, which improved the carbon deposit gasification rate [31]. The CH4 and CO2 molar conversion of the CeO2 coated catalysts are higher than those of the uncoated catalysts at any time period, and the reduction in their CH4 and CO2 conversion occurred at an increasingly gradual rate. Indeed, the catalytic performance of Ni/MSS@CeO2 showed a 9.1 % drop in CH4 molar conversion (from 0.219 to 0.199 mol·min−1·gNi−1) and a 7.5 % drop in CO2 molar conversion (from 0.286 to 0.265 mol·min−1·gNi−1). The decreases in CH4 and CO2 molar conversions were 20 % and 15.9 % for Ni/SiO2@CeO2, which suggest that the CeO2 coating effectively enhances the durability. This is because the CeO2 shell efficiently prevents Ni particles from sintering, and its oxygen vacancies greatly reduce the production of carbon deposition. In addition, as shown in Fig. S7b, the Ni/CeO2 catalyst exhibited an 11 % reduction in CH4 molar conversion (from 0.055 to 0.049 mol·min−1·gNi−1) alongside an 8.1 % decrease in CO2 molar conversion (0.074–0.068 mol·min−1·gNi−1). This again shows that the oxygen vacancies provided by CeO2 effectively inhibit the formation of carbon deposits. The sandwich structure catalyst's carbon balance is closer to 100 % throughout the whole process (Fig. S6b), indicating that it has excellent anti-carbon deposition ability. 3.5 Catalysts characterization after reaction The N2 isotherms and pore size curve of catalyst after the reaction have no obvious changes relative to its pre-reaction state (Fig. S9). This demonstrates remarkable morphological stability of the catalyst, maintaining its original morphology throughout the catalytic process. However, the specific surface areas of all used catalysts increased to a certain extent (Table 1), as a result of the reaction producing carbon deposits. The pore volume for Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS decreased after the reaction, while the pore volume for Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 did not change. This demonstrates that the layer of CeO2 successfully prevents the carbon deposits into the support pores. This won't stop the reaction gas and active Ni particles from coming into contact, thereby maintaining the excellent catalyst stability. Fig. 7a-c and Fig. S10 depicts the TEM picture of the catalyst that has been used. All the catalysts remained spherical, indicating excellent thermal stability. The Ni/SiO2 catalyst exhibits an abundance of filamentous carbon (Fig. 7a), and the Ni particles were aggregated as they detached from the SiO2 surface. Usually, the nickel surface is not rendered inactive by filamentous carbon. However, it will increase the reactor bed temperature and terminate the reaction [33,60]. Additionally, minute carbon deposits were discovered on the previously utilized Ni/MSS surface, and Ni particles were also found to be sintered (Fig. S10). The used Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS catalyst's Ni particle diameters were 9.3 nm and 7.3 nm (Fig. S11), respectively, bigger than those of the reduced catalysts by 10.6 % and 22.3 %. This indicates that the peculiar pore structure effectively prevents the Ni particles from clustering. After the reaction, carbon deposition was minimal on Ni/SiO2@CeO2 (Fig. 7b). However, there was no evidence of carbon deposition on Ni/MS@CeO2 (Fig. 7c). At the same time, there was no obvious sintering of Ni particles on both catalysts, which indicates that the sandwich structure formed by the CeO2 coating boosts durability against carbon deposition and moving. The Ni diffraction peak intensity of Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS (Fig. 7d) increased significantly after reaction, signaling that the Ni particles underwent agglomeration. The Scherrer formula determined that the Ni crystal sizes for Ni/SiO2 and Ni/MSS samples are 8.8 nm and 6.2 nm. In comparison to the reduced catalyst, they increased by 14.3 % and 8.8 %. This demonstrates that the inverted cone pore efficiently prevents the Ni particles from clustering. The strength of the Ni diffraction peak for the catalyst with a coating remained unchanged (Fig. S12a and b), indicating that the sandwich structure formed by CeO2 coating avoids the Ni particles clustering. For both Ni/MSS and Ni/SiO2, a distinct carbon (C) diffraction peak emerges at 25.9° post-reaction [61,62], and the intensity of Ni/SiO2 was higher. Fortunately, Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 did not show the diffraction peak of C. This shows that the coating of CeO2 significantly prevented the carbon deposits. Interestingly, after the reaction, the Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 diffraction peak intensity for Ni/MSS@CeO2 weakened, while the intensity increased for Ni/SiO2@CeO2. This is because the oxidizing ability of CO2 during the reforming process will cause Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 to transform into CeO2 and SiO2 crystalline phases, and Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 with low crystallinity is more easily oxidized [51]. To determine the quantity of carbon, a TG study was conducted. All catalysts exhibit a minor mass loss below 250 °C, attributed to water desorption [63]. Above this temperature (250–400 °C), a slight mass increase is observed in the TG profile (Fig. 7e), resulting from nickel oxidation [4,64]. Subsequently, a pronounced decline is observed, attributable to the combustion of accumulated carbon deposits. The carbon deposit of Ni/SiO2 reached 34.29 %, after only 8 h of reaction, which is attributed to its larger Ni particles. The amount of carbon deposits measured after 30 h reaction time was highest for Ni/MSS (22.55 %), followed by Ni/SiO2@CeO2 (12.99 %), with Ni/MSS@CeO2 showing the lowest accumulation (5.83 %). This is because small-particle Ni is difficult to create carbon deposits, and MSS's inverted cone pore shape enhances Ni dispersion. The CeO2 covering exhibits a significant abundance of oxygen vacancies, and can oxidize the generated carbon deposits. Simultaneously, the CeO2-coated catalyst's strong basicity also enhances the speed of carbon deposits gasification and diminishes carbon deposits. The abundant oxygen vacancies, strong basicity, and unique pore structure inherent in MSS synergistically lead to minimal carbon deposition in Ni/MSS@CeO2. As presented in Fig. S13, the primary weight loss peaks occurred at different temperatures for each catalyst: Ni/SiO2 (628 °C), Ni/SiO2@CeO2 (605 °C), Ni/MSS (648 °C), and Ni/MSS@CeO2 (598 °C). In general, carbon deposits with a lesser degree of graphitization are more susceptible to oxidation. This shows that the coating of CeO2 also improves the type of carbon deposits. Different types of carbon deposits are further investigated using O2-TPO and Raman studies. All catalysts displayed characteristic Raman bands at 1344 cm−1 (D-band) and 1587 cm−1 (G-band), indicating the coexistence of amorphous and graphitized carbon species (Fig. 7f) [48,65]. The graphitization extent of carbon deposits can be assessed by calculating the intensity ratio between the G-band (1587 cm−1) and D-band (1344 cm−1) in the Raman spectra [66]. The IG/ID ratios followed the order: Ni/MSS (0.89) > Ni/SiO2 (0.82) > Ni/SiO2@CeO2 (0.72) > Ni/MSS@CeO2 (0.70), which means that the CeO2 layer greatly diminishes the level of carbon deposits' graphitization. The used Ni/SiO2@CeO2, Ni/MSS and Ni/SiO2 catalysts' O2-TPO curves were split into two peaks, β and γ (Fig. 7g). The Ni/MSS@CeO2 was resolved into three constituent peaks (α, β, and γ) through curve fitting analysis. The carbon deposits can be categorized based on their removal temperatures: activated carbon (Cα), which is easily eliminated, is typically removed below 450 °C [60]. Filamentous carbon (Cβ) is decomposed between 450 and 650 °C, while inert carbon (Cγ) requires temperatures above 650 °C for removal [64]. The minimal peak area for Ni/MSS@CeO2 (Table S11) quantitatively confirms its lowest carbon accumulation among the tested catalysts. The peak area of Ni/SiO2 was 1.9 times that of Ni/MSS, which reveals that the MSS's pore structure is an essential component in limiting the carbon deposits production. The catalyst's peak area was much diminished after being coated with CeO2, indicating that CeO2 effectively hinders the production of carbon deposits. This aligns with the findings of the TG. In addition, the carbon deposits of Ni/SiO2 are inert carbon species with poor activity and difficult to oxidize. The carbon deposits of Ni/MSS@CeO2 are mainly fibrous carbon, accompanied by trace amounts of reactive carbon species. The carbon deposits of Ni/SiO2@CeO2 also contain a large amount of inert carbon species, resulting in poor stability. This indicates that CeO2 can improve the carbon deposit species from inactive carbon species that are challenging to eliminate into active carbon species that can be easily removed. 3.6 Kinetic studies To elucidate the role of CeO2 coating in catalytic performance, comprehensive kinetic tests were systematically carried out for the DRM process. Under the same conditions, sandwich catalysts had higher TOFCH4 and TOFCO2 than Ni/MSS and Ni/SiO2 (Table S12). The lowest CH4 and CO2 activation energies are found in Ni/MSS@CeO2, with EaCH4 = 48.5 kJ/mol and EaCO2 = 45.4 kJ/mol ( Fig. 8). The CH4 activation energies for Ni/MSS, Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2 are 59.8 kJ/mol, 56.0 kJ/mol and 64.0 kJ/mol. This suggests that MSS's distinct pore structure boosts the Ni dispersion, and its pore structure promotes the diffusion rate of CH4, allowing it to quickly contact active metal sites, effectively improving the activation ability of CH4. Compared with the uncoated CeO2 catalyst, numerous oxygen vacancies are provided by the CeO2 layer to encourage CH4 activation, thereby reducing the activation energy for CH4 cracking. Meanwhile, the CH4 cracking activation energy is greatly reduced by the abundance of Ni-O-Ce active sites in Ni/MSS@CeO2. The catalyst's CO2 cracking activation energy is smaller compared to their CH4 cracking activation energy, owning to the reverse water gas reaction [67]. The CO2 activation energies of Ni/SiO2@CeO2, Ni/MSS and Ni/SiO2 were 48.4 kJ/mol, 55.2 kJ/mol and 58.9 kJ/mol. Ni/MSS@CeO2 exhibits the lowest activation energy for CO2 cracking, demonstrating that the CeO2 coating boosts oxygen vacancy formation and alkalinity, thereby significantly improving CO2 adsorption efficiency, and causes the activation energy required to split CO2 to significantly decrease. At the same time, the high crystallinity of cerium silicate is thermally stable and has weak redox ability, which results in Ni/SiO2@CeO2 having a lower capacity to crack CO2 than Ni/MSS@CeO2. 3.7 Mechanism of oxygen vacancies in removing carbon deposits To investigate how oxygen vacancies in the sandwich structure catalyst contribute to methane activation, we conducted CH4-TPSR experiments on catalysts. The CH4 decomposes rapidly on the Ni/MSS catalyst starting from 430 ℃ and stops decomposing after 750 ℃ (Fig. S14a). This is due to the fact that the Ni surface of the active site is covered by carbon deposits produced by the breakdown of CH4, resulting in loss of activity [12]. Correspondingly, a large amount of H2 is produced starting from 430 ℃ (Fig. S14c). However, almost no CO and CO2 are produced during the entire experiment (Fig. S14b and S14d). In contrast, CH4 on the Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 decomposes slowly starting from 200 ℃ and 260 ℃, respectively ( Fig. 9a), and continues to decompose throughout the process, demonstrating that the presence of oxygen vacancies inhibits the deep cracking of CH4 and prevents the creation of carbon deposits while simultaneously promoting the breakdown of CH4. The CH4 decomposition peak becomes progressively sharper with rising temperature, demonstrating that higher temperatures facilitate CH4 cracking. Simultaneously, Ni/SiO2@CeO2 and Ni/MSS@CeO2 began to produce CO from 300 ℃ and 250 ℃ and continued throughout the process (Fig. 9b), which shows that the oxygen vacancies promote the generation of CO. At the same time, a small amount of CO2 was generated from 200 ℃ and 250 ℃, and CO2 was no longer generated at 500 ℃ (Fig. 9d). This may be because the generated CO2 reacted with the generated carbon deposits to improve the CH4 cracking ability. Interestingly, both CH4 cracking and H2 production peak intensities are significantly higher for Ni/MSS than for Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 catalysts (Fig. 9c), which was because the Ni content of Ni/MSS is higher. It also shows that the active sites for CH4 cracking are mainly Ni particles, and oxygen vacancies primarily diminish the extensive cracking of CH4 to prevent carbon deposit growth and continuously crack CH4. However, in the absence of CO2, CO was generated, indicating that oxygen vacancies are also active sites for the DRM reaction [11]. Ni/MSS@CeO2 has a lower CH4 cracking temperature and stronger CH4 cracking ability relative to Ni/SiO2@CeO2 because it has more Ni-O-Ce sites and stronger Ni-Ce interactions [14]. To investigate the function of oxygen vacancies in CO2 activation, the catalysts underwent CO2-TPSR investigation. No significant variations in CO2 and CO evolution were detected by mass spectrometry during the entire catalytic process over Ni/MSS, which indicates the weak CO2 activation ability of Ni particles (Fig. S15a). In contrast, Ni/MSS@CeO2 initiated gradual decomposition at 350 ℃, while Ni/SiO2@CeO2 commenced at 500 °C, both processes being concomitant with CO evolution (Fig. S15b). This demonstrate that the oxygen vacancies generated by the sandwich-structured catalyst function as effective active centers for CO2 adsorption and conversion. Interestingly, despite Ni/SiO2@CeO2 possessing a greater number of oxygen vacancies, it requires higher temperatures for CO2 decomposition than Ni/MSS@CeO2. This is attributed to the formation of excellent crystallinity, remarkable thermal stability and weak redox ability of the Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 phase formed upon reduction. The oxygen vacancies it provides being restricted by the rigid skeleton of SiO4 and are relatively weak in the ability to adsorb and activate CO2, which aligns with the findings of CO2-TPD and kinetic tests. 3.8 Mechanism analysis To obtain a more profound comprehension of the DRM reaction pathway, we executed an investigation into its reaction mechanism utilizing in situ DRIFT technology. The Fig. S16a and S16b show the DRIFT total spectra of CH4 over Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/MSS as the temperature increases. As illustrated by Fig. 10, the peak between 3500 cm−1 and 3800 cm−1 is the surface OH species, and the peaks at 1304 cm−1 and 3016 cm−1 line up with CH4 absorption [11,41]. Spectral features observed at 2340 and 2360 cm−1 are attributed to CO2 [68]. Spectral features observed at 1940 cm and 2095 cm−1 were bridging CO* and linear CO* adsorbed on the active site Ni, and the peak at 2198 cm−1 is gas phase CO [33,47,68]. The characteristic vibrational bands observed at 1645 cm−1 and 1610 cm−1 are assigned to the COO stretching modes of surface bicarbonate (HCO3*) and formate (HCO2*) [69,70]. The COO vibration peaks from carbonate (CO3*) appeared at 1540 cm−1, 1469 cm−1, and 1415 cm−1 [70]. The peaks at 1354 cm−1 and 1341 cm−1 are CH3* species [71]. In the CH4 atmosphere, the intensity of OH species for Ni/MSS@CeO2 increases with the temperature, showing that surface oxygen promotes the activation of methane (Fig. 10a-1) [72,73]. In contrast, the OH peak intensity of the Ni/MSS catalyst does not change significantly (Fig. S17a-1). Spectroscopic identification of CH3* groups verifies that methane dissociation takes place preferentially on the Ni active sites of the catalyst (Figs. 10a-6 and S17a-6). The strength of the CH4 peak diminishes with temperature, indicating that high temperature advocates the cracking of CH4, while the reduction of CH3* species indicates that it has been converted (Fig. 10a-2 and a-6). The sequential detection of bicarbonate, carbonate and formate species strongly suggests their role as key surface intermediates in the DRM reaction pathway (Fig. 10a-5). Normally, the CO2 adsorption and activation on OH and oxygen vacancies would generate bicarbonate and carbonate. The lack of a CO2 atmosphere here (Fig. 10a-2) suggests that surface oxygen species can react with the carbon species that result from methane cracking (3 O* + CHx* → HCO3* + (x-1)H*) [58,72]. At the same time, high temperature leads to its transformation to carbonate species. In addition, the peak intensity of bicarbonate species diminishes with evolving reaction temperature while the formate and carbonate species peak intensity become stronger (Fig. 10a-5). This indicates that bicarbonate is an active intermediate in the reaction, which can react with H* species to form formate (HCO3* + 2H* →HCO2* + H2O) [70]. Then it decomposes to produce CO. In contrast, the Ni/MSS catalyst has no obvious CO and carbonate peaks (Fig. S17a-4 and a-5), which demonstrate that excessive CH4 cracking occurs on Ni/MSS, leading to substantial carbon deposition that ultimately degrades catalytic performance in DRM. As the temperature rises, the CO2 DRIFT total spectra for both Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/MSS are presented in Fig. S18a and b. As shown in Fig. 10b-3 and S17b-3, strong CO2 adsorption peaks (2340 and 2360 cm−1) appeared in the CO2 atmosphere [68]. Meanwhile, the CO2 adsorbed on the catalyst interacts with surface oxygen species or OH species to produce peaks of bicarbonate and carbonate species (Fig. 10b-5 and S17b-5) [33], and their peak intensities are higher than those in the CH4 atmosphere. The peak intensity of CO2 drops as temperature rises, whereas the peak intensity of CO rises (Fig. 10b-4), suggesting that CO2 is straightaway adsorbed and dissociated to yield CO* and O* species on the Ni surface or the catalyst's oxygen vacancies [33,68]. At the same time, the O* filled in the oxygen vacancies will migrate and promptly reacted with the methane dissociation products to regenerate the oxygen vacancies [11,74]. However, Ni/MSS only has bridging CO* (1940 cm) adsorbed on the active site Ni (Figs. S17b-4), which suggests that the Ni/MSS has reduced CO2 cracking efficiency relative to Ni/MSS@CeO2. As seen in Fig. S19a and Fig. 10c, the Ni/MSS@CeO2 exhibits peaks of absorbed CO2 and CH4 in the mixed CH4/CO2 atmosphere. The peak intensity progressively drops, and the peak of CO arises as the reaction temperature rises, suggesting that both CH4 and CO2 have been converted (Fig. 10c-2 and c-3). The peak intensity of OH weakens with increasing temperature (Fig. 10c-1), indicating that the product (CHx* (x = 0–3) or H*) produced by the cracking of CH4 reacts with it. At the same time, the peak intensity of bicarbonate weakens and even becomes a negative peak with increasing reaction temperature. On the contrary, the peak intensity of formate and carbonate becomes stronger, indicating that bicarbonate is an active reaction intermediate that can combine with H* to form carbonate and CO* [58,72]. This is consistent with the above analysis results. Interestingly, when CH4 and CO2 exist simultaneously, the peak intensities of bicarbonate and carbonate are higher than those when CH4 or CO2 exists alone. This indicates that, on the one hand, CO2 generates bicarbonate or carbonate at OH or oxygen vacancy sites. In addition, the products generated by methane cracking react with surface oxygen species to form bicarbonate [68], which is converted into carbonate at high temperature. Under CH4 and CO2 atmospheres (Figs. S19b and S17c), the in-situ DRIFT spectra of Ni/MSS exhibit close resemblance to those of Ni/MSS@CeO2. But, because it has fewer oxygen vacancies, the active intermediate bicarbonate can only come from the adsorption activation of CO2 on OH, thus resulting in less CO production. Therefore, in summary, the reaction mechanism over Ni/MSS and Ni/MSS@CeO2 was displayed in Fig. 11. The Ni/MSS@CeO2 follows a bifunctional mechanism. On the active Ni-O-Ce interface, methane is adsorbed and activated, producing H* and CHx* species. CO2 is adsorbed and activated at the Ni-CeO2 interface. First, the carbon species produced by methane cracking interact with surface oxygen species (O*) on the catalyst, forming bicarbonate (HCO3*). Subsequently, these bicarbonate species along with those derived from CO2 activation react with hydrogen species (H*) to yield formate (HCOO*). Then, it further decomposes into CO* to produce CO. Secondly, CO2 directly dissociates into CO* or O* at oxygen vacancies, and then generates CO. The dry reforming of methane over the Ni/MSS catalyst proceeds via a monofunctional reaction mechanism, which CH4 and CO2 are adsorbed and activated on the active metal Ni surface. Fewer oxygen vacancies and weaker basicity of the catalyst lead to less bicarbonate intermediates and thus less CO. This aligns with the observed catalytic performance outcomes of the catalyst. Simultaneously, after coating with CeO2, the catalyst exhibits abundant oxygen vacancies sites. The adsorbed active oxygen species react with methane dissociation intermediates, leading to formate formation, which effectively avoiding the deep cracking of CH4 (CH4 → C + H2) to generate carbon deposits. At the same time, its strong CO2 adsorption capacity can quickly gasify the carbon deposits, significantly enhancing the catalyst's carbon deposition resistance. Despite the presence of numerous oxygen vacancies in Ni/SiO2@CeO2, the redox capacity of extremely crystalline Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 is weak, and the oxygen vacancies generated exhibit limited CO2 adsorption and activation capacity, consequently yielding reduced quantities of active oxygen species. Therefore, the carbon deposition rate is significantly higher than that observed for Ni/MSS@CeO2. 4 Conclusions In summary, the pores of the MSS facilitate the dispersion of active metals and inhibit the clustering of Ni particles. The fine Ni particles and unique pores avoid the emergence of carbon deposits to a certain extent. The sandwich structure catalyst coated with CeO2 significantly improves the stability of DRM. High-temperature H2 reduction greatly increases the number of oxygen vacancies in the sandwich structure catalyst comprising a CeO2 shell and SiO2 support layer. The dual confinement effect of MSS's pore structure and CeO2 shell layer prevented Ni particles from sintering. The unique pore of MSS promotes the dispersion of CeO2 and Ni, thereby constructing more Ni-O-Ce active sites and enhancing the Ni-CeO2 interaction. Moreover, the oxygen vacancies supplied by the CeO2 shell dramatically inhibit carbon deposition and reduce the degree of graphitization. Ni/SiO2@CeO2 has more oxygen vacancies, but as a result of the high crystallinity, poor redox ability and strong thermal of Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2, the oxygen vacancies it generated cannot fully activate CO2 and CH4, and also cover some active sites of Ni. Kinetic experiments revealed that the CeO2 shell sandwich catalyst exhibits a low CO2 and CH4 decomposition activation energy. Furthermore, in situ DRIFT technology proves that Ni/MSS@CeO2 follows the bifunctional DRM mechanism and the HCOO* path. The oxygen species promptly react with the carbon species generated by CH4 cracking, preventing severe CH4 decomposition and the accumulation of carbon deposits. This work present valuable insights for the design and preparation of high-efficiency Ni-SiO2-CeO2 system catalysts for DRM applications. coredata.dc:description: The low-temperature carbon deposition resistance of Ni-based DRM catalysts supported on inert SiO2 can be improved by constructing oxygen vacancies. This work deeply explored the role of monodispersed mesoporous silica spheres (MSS) and non-porous SiO2 support layer structure on the structure and oxygen vacancies of sandwich Ni/MSS@CeO2 and Ni/SiO2@CeO2 catalysts and their catalytic performance. The results show that Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2 generated by high-temperature H2 reduction greatly increases the number of oxygen vacancies. In comparison to non-porous SiO2, the dual confinement effect of MSS's pore and CeO2 shell layer prevented Ni particles from sintering. The unique pore of MSS promotes the dispersion of Ni and CeO2, constructing more Ni-O-Ce active sites and enhancing the Ni-CeO2 interaction. It has low activation energy for decomposition of CH4 and CO2. In addition, the oxygen vacancies provided by the CeO2 shell notably inhibit carbon deposition and reduce the degree of graphitization. Ni/SiO2@CeO2 has more oxygen vacancies, but due to the high crystallinity, weak redox ability and strong thermal stability of Ce9.33(SiO4)6O2, the oxygen vacancies it produces cannot fully activate CH4 and CO2, and also cover some active sites of Ni. Ni/MSS@CeO2 resulted in minimal carbon deposits during a 30 h reaction under low-temperature and high space velocity. In situ DRIFT technology confirmed that Ni/MSS@CeO2 follows the HCOO* pathway. The oxygen species can react with the carbon species produced by CH4 decomposition. This work offers valuable insights for the design of efficient Ni-SiO2-CeO2 catalysts.
